ind2=" "><subfield code="a">An overview of modern solution NMR -- An introduction to spin and nuclear magnetism -- Early NMR experiments and some practical considerations -- Chemical information from resonance frequencies: Chemical shifts, dipolar coupling, and scalar coupling -- The pulse NMR method: The pulse -- The pulse NMR method: The signal and spectrum -- Relaxation -- A more mathematical look at molecular motion and NMR relaxation -- Cross-relaxation and the nuclear Overhauser effect -- Two-dimensional NMR experiments -- The mathematical formalism of quantum mechanics -- More quantum mechanics: Time and energy -- Quantum description of a scalar-coupled spin pair -- NMR spectroscopy of a weakly coupled spin pair -- Two-dimensional spectra based on scalar coupling: COSY and TOCSY experiments -- Heteronuclear NMR techniques -- Introduction to the density matrix -- Basis sets for the density matrix and the product-operator formalism -- Appendix A: List of symbols, numerical constants and abbreviations -- Appendix B: Trigonometric functions and complex numbers -- Appendix C: Fourier series and transforms -- Appendix D: Vectors and matrices -- Appendix E: Mathematics for uncoupled spin-1/2 particles -- Appendix F: Mathematics of the two-spin system.</subfield></datafield><datafield tag="520" ind1=" " ind2=" "><subfield code="a">"With nearly 400 original illustrations, this NMR primer provides an introduction to solution NMR spectroscopy at a level appropriate for advanced undergraduates, graduate students and working scientists with backgrounds in chemistry or biochemistry. It presents the underlying physics and mathematics in a way that is both accessible and sufficiently complete to allow a real understanding of modern multi-dimensional experiments, thereby giving readers the tools they need to move to more advanced textbooks and articles. One special feature of this text is a thorough, but accessible, treatment of spin quantum mechanics, including scalar-coupled spins. A novel style of vector diagram is used to represent the quantum correlations between coupled spins and the manipulation of these correlations by pulses and time evolution. This will help to clarify what is arguably the most difficult aspect of NMR for students and practitioners to master." -- Publisher's description</subfield></datafield><datafield tag="650" ind1=" " ind2="0"><subfield code="a">Nuclear magnetic resonance spectroscopy.</subfield></datafield><datafield tag="650" ind1=" " ind2="7"><subfield code="a">Nuclear magnetic resonance spectroscopy.</subfield><subfield code="2">fast</subfield><subfield code="0">(OCoLC)fst01040333</subfield></datafield><datafield tag="949" ind1=" " ind2=" "><subfield code="a">QD96.N8G625 2016</subfield><subfield code="w">LC</subfield><subfield code="c">1</subfield><subfield code="i">000078500051</subfield><subfield code="d">10/7/2020</subfield><subfield code="e">12/9/2017</subfield><subfield code="l">STACKS-EM</subfield><subfield code="m">UP-EMS</subfield><subfield code="n">3</subfield><subfield code="r">Y</subfield><subfield code="s">Y</subfield><subfield code="t">BOOK</subfield><subfield code="u">6/13/2016</subfield></datafield></record>
all_text_timv: Goldenberg, David P., 1954- author. Principles of NMR spectroscopy : an illustrated guide / David P. Goldenberg, University of Utah. Principles of nuclear magnetic resonance spectroscopy Mill Valley, California : University Science Books, [2016] ©2016 xxii, 681 pages : illustrations (some color) ; 26 cm text txt rdacontent unmediated n rdamedia volume nc rdacarrier Includes bibliographical references and index. An overview of modern solution NMR -- An introduction to spin and nuclear magnetism -- Early NMR experiments and some practical considerations -- Chemical information from resonance frequencies: Chemical shifts, dipolar coupling, and scalar coupling -- The pulse NMR method: The pulse -- The pulse NMR method: The signal and spectrum -- Relaxation -- A more mathematical look at molecular motion and NMR relaxation -- Cross-relaxation and the nuclear Overhauser effect -- Two-dimensional NMR experiments -- The mathematical formalism of quantum mechanics -- More quantum mechanics: Time and energy -- Quantum description of a scalar-coupled spin pair -- NMR spectroscopy of a weakly coupled spin pair -- Two-dimensional spectra based on scalar coupling: COSY and TOCSY experiments -- Heteronuclear NMR techniques -- Introduction to the density matrix -- Basis sets for the density matrix and the product-operator formalism -- Appendix A: List of symbols, numerical constants and abbreviations -- Appendix B: Trigonometric functions and complex numbers -- Appendix C: Fourier series and transforms -- Appendix D: Vectors and matrices -- Appendix E: Mathematics for uncoupled spin-1/2 particles -- Appendix F: Mathematics of the two-spin system. "With nearly 400 original illustrations, this NMR primer provides an introduction to solution NMR spectroscopy at a level appropriate for advanced undergraduates, graduate students and working scientists with backgrounds in chemistry or biochemistry. It presents the underlying physics and mathematics in a way that is both accessible and sufficiently complete to allow a real understanding of modern multi-dimensional experiments, thereby giving readers the tools they need to move to more advanced textbooks and articles. One special feature of this text is a thorough, but accessible, treatment of spin quantum mechanics, including scalar-coupled spins. A novel style of vector diagram is used to represent the quantum correlations between coupled spins and the manipulation of these correlations by pulses and time evolution. This will help to clarify what is arguably the most difficult aspect of NMR for students and practitioners to master." -- Publisher's description Nuclear magnetic resonance spectroscopy. Nuclear magnetic resonance spectroscopy. fast (OCoLC)fst01040333

notes_summary_ssim: "With nearly 400 original illustrations, this NMR primer provides an introduction to solution NMR spectroscopy at a level appropriate for advanced undergraduates, graduate students and working scientists with backgrounds in chemistry or biochemistry. It presents the underlying physics and mathematics in a way that is both accessible and sufficiently complete to allow a real understanding of modern multi-dimensional experiments, thereby giving readers the tools they need to move to more advanced textbooks and articles. One special feature of this text is a thorough, but accessible, treatment of spin quantum mechanics, including scalar-coupled spins. A novel style of vector diagram is used to represent the quantum correlations between coupled spins and the manipulation of these correlations by pulses and time evolution. This will help to clarify what is arguably the most difficult aspect of NMR for students and practitioners to master." -- Publisher's description
